entry.title: An intuitive understanding of matrices
entry.content:
Matrices and their Intuition

Many of us have probably encountered matrices at some point but in math class. They’re this little awkward tables with seemingly byzantine rules for multiplying and inverting them. We all probably learned how to operate on them at some point but how did someone come up with them? Where do these rules for multiplication and inversion even come from? In short, what’s the underlying intuition for matrices?

I really think it’s worth answering this question because we use matrices in almost every field of engineering but often times don’t appreciate what they mean. To me it’s not too different from applying multiplication tables without fully appreciating what numbers are.

So let’s try and rectify that a litte. Through this post, I’m going to share my intuition of matrices and why they represent such a powerful idea. We’re going to do so by starting with the idea of linear functions and then using that knowledge to derive matrices.

Linear functions

Linear functions are the foundations of matrices. One example is f(x)=3xf(x) = 3xf(x)=3x for real numbers xxx. Their main rules are as follows:

  • f(c⋅x)=c⋅f(x) f(c \cdot x) = c \cdot f(x) f(c⋅x)=c⋅f(x)
    • Can multiply by a scalar before or after applying by the function and get the same result.
    • For our example, f(5⋅x)=3⋅5x=15x=5⋅f(x)f(5\cdot x) = 3 \cdot 5x = 15x = 5 \cdot f(x)f(5⋅x)=3⋅5x=15x=5⋅f(x).
  • f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y) f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y) f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y)
    • Can add before or after applying the function and get the same result.
    • For our example, f(x+y)=3⋅(x+y)=3x+3y=f(x)+f(y)f(x + y) = 3 \cdot (x + y) = 3x + 3y = f(x) + f(y)f(x+y)=3⋅(x+y)=3x+3y=f(x)+f(y).

Early mathematicians realized that such functions can model a lot of the phenomena that happen in the real world from physics, to statistics. Here are a few other examples of linear functions in geometry:

  • Rotations
    • A function that rotates an shape around a point.
    • .
  • Scaling
    • A function that takes a 2d image and makes it 2x as large.

Representing Functions

So we now know what linear functions are and we’ve seen how they represent many physical phenomena - but how can we succintly represent them? Taking a step back, how do we represent functions in general? One way is to simply have a table that takes every input and displays its output. For instance, we could write:

xxx f(x)f(x)f(x)
1 2
2 4
3 6

But this can much more easily be written as f(x)=2x f(x) = 2x f(x)=2x. This representation, a polynomial, is powerful. How? For example let’s say I have another function g(x)=10xg(x) = 10xg(x)=10x. Imagine someone asks me, “what happens if I apply fff, followed by ggg?”

Before I had this representation, I would have had to make a full table where I write out f(x), and then apply g(x) on it per input like below:

xxx f(x)f(x)f(x) g(f(x))g(f(x))g(f(x))
1 2 20
2 4 40
3 6 60

But now that we have a the polynomial representation, we can just do g(x)=10xg(x) = 10xg(x)=10x g(f(x))=10f(x)g(f(x)) = 10f(x)g(f(x))=10f(x) g(f(x))=10⋅2xg(f(x)) = 10\cdot 2xg(f(x))=10⋅2x g(f(x))=20xg(f(x)) = 20xg(f(x))=20x

Now, in a few simple steps, immediately figure out g(f(x))g(f(x))g(f(x)). The same is true of g(x)+f(x)g(x) + f(x)g(x)+f(x), g(x)⋅f(x)g(x) \cdot f(x)g(x)⋅f(x) etc.

In short, the right representation allows us to succintly understand, combine, and process functions in extremely powerful ways.

Representing Linear Functions

Returning to linear functions, how can we easily represent them?

1-dimension

Let’s start with linear functions that take in real numbers and return real numbers (all in 1 dimension - the real line).

Let's start with linear functions that take inputs on the real line and return outputs on the real line

These linear transforms will always be written simply as f(x)=mxf(x) = mxf(x)=mx for some mmm. So the representation for linear functions that operate in one dimension is easy.

2-dimensions

But what about in 2 dimensions (i.e. the input is a vector [10]\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[10​])?

Now, let's focus on linear functions that operate on 2d vectors.

Let’s take a new function f(x)f(x)f(x). Let’s just start by describing what the function does to two of the most basic vectors

[10]\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[10​] and [01]\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[01​].

We define:

f([10])=[30]f(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}) = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}f([10​])=[30​] f([01])=[05]f(\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}) = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix}f([01​])=[05​]

Based on this, can I figure out f[109]f\begin{bmatrix} 10 \\ 9\end{bmatrix}f[109​] is? Amazingly, yes! Because this is a linear function, we see that

f([109])=f([100])+f([09])f(\begin{bmatrix} 10 \\ 9\end{bmatrix}) = f(\begin{bmatrix} 10 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}) + f(\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 9\end{bmatrix})f([109​])=f([100​])+f([09​]) =10⋅f([10])+9⋅f([01]) = 10 \cdot f(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}) + 9 \cdot f(\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix})=10⋅f([10​])+9⋅f([01​]) =10⋅[30]+9⋅[05] = 10 \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + 9\cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix}=10⋅[30​]+9⋅[05​] =[300]+[045] = \begin{bmatrix} 30 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 45 \end{bmatrix}=[300​]+[045​] =[3045] = \begin{bmatrix} 30 \\ 45 \end{bmatrix}=[3045​]

What this shows is that we can represent the function entirely by what it does to the vectors [10]\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[10​] and [01]\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[01​].

I would put this sentence before your actual multiplication above ^ and then draw visual diagrams from f(10,9) to the (1,0) and (0,1) former and latter 1’s specifically. As a visual learner the diagram would help connect the dots much faster.

Matrices

Ok so is there a way I can succintly describe what a function does to [10]\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[10​] and [01]\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[01​]?

Yes!

A simple 2x2 matrix can do just this!

f(x)f(x)f(x) can be represented by the notation [f([10])f([01])]\begin{bmatrix} f(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}) & f(\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}) \end{bmatrix}[f([10​])​f([01​])​] [3005] \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix} [30​05​]

This is extremely cool - we can describe the entire function and how it operates on an infinite number of points by a little 4 value table.

So just like whenever you see f(x)=2x+3f(x) = 2x + 3f(x)=2x+3, you immediately know you’re dealing with a function, next time you see a matrix, know that you are dealing with a shorthand for a linear function. It’s the f(x)=mxf(x) = mxf(x)=mx of the linear world.

Understanding Matrix Multiplication

Ok so we know that a matrix represents a function - but how do we apply this function on an input?

Specifically, say I have the same function fff which we described by the matrix F=[3005]F = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix} F=[30​05​]. I want to apply this function on the vector [xy] \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} [xy​]. How do we do it?

Let’s start with what we know. The first column of the matrix tells us f([10])f(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix})f([10​]) and the second column tells us f([01])f(\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix})f([01​]).

To make use of that, let’s break [xy]\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}[xy​] into a combination of [10]\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}[10​] and [01]\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[01​].

[xy]=x⋅[10]+y⋅[01]\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = x \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + y \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[xy​]=x⋅[10​]+y⋅[01​]

f([xy])=f(x⋅[10])+y⋅[01]) f(\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}) = f(x \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}) + y \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix})f([xy​])=f(x⋅[10​])+y⋅[01​])

Thanks to the amazing properties of linear functions (f(a+b)=f(a)+f(b)f(a+b) = f(a) + f(b)f(a+b)=f(a)+f(b)), we can now simplify this to:

=f(x⋅[10])+f(y⋅[01]) = f(x \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}) + f(y \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix})=f(x⋅[10​])+f(y⋅[01​])

And then using another property of linear functions (f(c⋅a)=c⋅f(a)f(c \cdot a) = c\cdot f(a)f(c⋅a)=c⋅f(a)),

=x⋅f([10])+y⋅f([01]) = x\cdot f(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}) + y \cdot f(\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix})=x⋅f([10​])+y⋅f([01​])

And now we apply the knowledge we have (from the columns of the matrix)!

=x⋅[30]+y⋅[05] = x \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + y\cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix}=x⋅[30​]+y⋅[05​] f([xy])=[3x+0y0x+5y]f(\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}) = \begin{bmatrix} 3x + 0y \\ 0x + 5y \end{bmatrix}f([xy​])=[3x+0y0x+5y​]

Does this look familiar? Because it is exactly what you would get by carrying out the matrix multiplication [3005]⋅[xy]\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}[30​05​]⋅[xy​]!

The matrix multiplication rule is just a shorthand for applying a function on a vector! This is really what’s happening under the scenes.

Matrix Multiplication as Function Composition

Ok so we’ve seen that multiplying a 2x2 matrix by a vector is just applying the function on the vector. But what does matrix multiplication when we are multiplying two 2x2 matrices?

To answer this, we’re going to take a small detour. We know how to apply a function fff on an input vector vvv. What if I ask you to find the composition h=g(f(v))h = g(f(v))h=g(f(v)) where we know fff and ggg?

Let’s work through this now:

Let G=[5916]G = \begin{bmatrix} 5 & 9 \\ 1 & 6 \end{bmatrix}G=[51​96​] (G is the matrix for the function g).

Let F=[3005]F = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix}F=[30​05​] as before.

We want to find the matrix HHH that represents the function h=g(f(v))h = g(f(v))h=g(f(v)).

This is going to be:

H=[g(f([10])g(f([01]))]H = \begin{bmatrix} g(f(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}) & g(f(\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix})) \end{bmatrix}H=[g(f([10​])​g(f([01​]))​]

Let’s call the first column of FFF Fcol1F_{col1}Fcol1​ and the second column Fcol2F_{col2}Fcol2​.

Then we can simplify to:

H=[g(Fcol1)g(Fcol2)]H = \begin{bmatrix} g(F_{col1}) & g(F_{col2}) \end{bmatrix} H=[g(Fcol1​)​g(Fcol2​)​]

So what’s g(Fcol1)g(F_{col1})g(Fcol1​)?

Well we just saw earlier that this is just G⋅Fcol1G \cdot F_{col1}G⋅Fcol1​. So we can now write:

H=[G⋅Fcol1G⋅Fcol2]H = \begin{bmatrix} G \cdot F_{col1} & G \cdot F_{col2} \end{bmatrix} H=[G⋅Fcol1​​G⋅Fcol2​​]

Seem familiar? Because it’s exactly what the formula for the 2x2 matrix multiplication H=G⋅FH = G\cdot FH=G⋅F! This shows that matrix multiplication can be thought of as function composition.

Thanks to matrix multiplication, we have amazingly simple rules for understanding g∘fg \circ fg∘f, f+gf+gf+g etc. without manually writing out a bunch of tables.

Combining Functions

Remember how much power we gained by being able to represent a function as a polynomial? We were able to combine polynomials, compose them, multiply them - we now have all that same power for linear functions! We can compose them (matrix multiplication), add them (matrix addition), and invert them (matrix inversion) all by following some simple rules.

A more sophisticated way of saying this is we have an algebra on these functions (just like we have an algebra on integers etc.). This is what linear algebra means - the ability to do combine and compose linear functions just as we combine and compose integers.

Imagine doing all this with input-output tables! It would be hell. Instead, we can now operate on these complex functions and combine them in all kinds of ways and immediately know the resulting function.

Looking Forward

So we’ve seen pretty clearly that matrices are just functions and that linear algebra is the study of combining linear functions.

Understanding this helps us perceive some of the key ideas of linear algebra in a new way. In the next post, we’re going to focus on eigenvectors and learn why they are so useful in playing with these functions.
